questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with heart failure with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction. What is the initial treatment of choice for this patient?

choices.text: Angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors and diuretics

questions.solution:
Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors and diuretics are the first-line treatment in patients with heart failure and decreased left ventricular ejection fraction.

This is usually followed by the addition of a beta blocker once there is adequate diuresis.

Note: SGLT2 inhibitors such as dapagliflozin and empagliflozin have shown a significant decrease in morbidity and mortality in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) and heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF).

questions.text: You are counseling a diabetic patient to consume foods with a low glycemic index. Which of the following food items would you advise this patient to eat?
questions.solution:
The patient should be advised to eat whole grains since it has low glycemic index (GI).

GI is a number representing the relative ability of a carbohydrate food to increase the level of glucose in the blood. It is calculated by comparing the test carbohydrate to the standard (glucose or white bread). This measure has practical use in the management of diabetes and obesity.

  • Low GI foods – most fruits and vegetables, whole grains, pasta foods, beans, and lentils
  • Moderate GI foods – sucrose, basmati rice, and brown rice
  • High GI foods – corn flakes, baked potatoes, white bread, potatoes, watermelon and sweet corn, candies and syrupy foods

questions.text: A patient presents with a backache to the surgery OPD.  Further investigations reveal nephrolithiasis. A microscopic examination of the patient's urine reveals a structure as shown in the image below. These stones are likely due to which of the following
questions.solution:
The microscopic examination of this patient's urine demonstrates hexagon-shaped crystals. This type of crystal is seen in patients with cystinuria.

Cystinuria is an autosomal recessive inherited defect involving cystine, ornithine, lysine, and arginine.

Cystine stones are often hexagon shaped and radioopaque.

    • Dihydrate: Octahedral or envelope shaped
  • Struvite stones: Rectangular or coffin lid

questions.text: A young patient is being administered cardiopulmonary resuscitation as per appropriate guidelines. Which of the following is an indicator of low-quality cardiopulmonary resuscitation?

choices.text: Chest compressions at the rate of 100-120/min
End tidal carbon dioxide <10 mm Hg
End tidal carbon dioxide >20 mm Hg

questions.solution:
CPR quality needs to be improved when end-tidal CO2(ETCO2) is less than 10 mm Hg. CPR can be considered to be high quality when ETCO2 is at least 10-20 mmHg.

ETCO2 is the level of carbon dioxide that is released at the end of an exhaled breath. It can be monitored with the help of capnometry and capnography.

This parameter is used to monitor a patient's ventilation status in real-time. Failure to maintain ETCO2 at >10 mm Hg during adult CPR is a reflection of poor cardiac output and it is found to strongly predicts unsuccessful resuscitation.

 

Related Pearl: High quality CPR for adults

  • Push hard: 5-6cm depth
  • Push fast: 100-120/min frequency
  • Allow for complete chest recoil
  • Minimize interruptions in compressions <10 seconds
  • Avoid excessive ventilation
  • Rotate compressor every 2 min or earlier if fatigued
  • If no advanced airway, 30:2 compression-ventilation ratio

Attempt to improve CPR quality if :

  • Quantitative waveform capnography - PETCO2 <10mmHg, 
  • Intra-arterial pressure - If relaxation phase (diastolic) pressure <20mmHg

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the outpatient department with the following lesion over the face. The patient also gives a history of recurrent bleeding and crusting since the onset of the lesion. On examination, the surgeon notices an ulcer with rolled-out/rodent ulcer borders. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is basal cell carcinoma(BCC).

Basal cell carcinoma is a malignant skin tumor occurring in the sun-exposed areas of the face such as the nose and other parts of the face.

The risk factors for developing this condition are:

  • UV exposure
  • Immune suppression
  • Ionizing radiation exposure

BCC is a locally aggressive neoplasm and patients present with a wide range of symptoms ranging from macule/patch with telangiectasia to ulcers with a characteristic rolled-out borders/rodent ulcer appearance.

questions.text: A patient with psoriatic arthritis presented to the outpatient department for initiation of treatment. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
In a patient with psoriatic arthritis, the treatment of choice is anti-tumor necrosis factor (anti-TNF) agents.

Psoriatic arthritis is an auto-immune musculoskeletal disease associated with psoriasis. In patients with this disease, an anti-TNF inhibitor is recommended as the first-line agent.

If anti-TNF agents are not tolerated then other drugs such as methotrexate may also be added. Examples of anti-TNF agents are Etanercept, Infliximab, and Adalimumab.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with acute onset of testicular pain. On examination, the left testis is enlarged and tender. The surgeon suspects a condition that is depicted in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is testicular torsion.

Testicular torsion is a condition that occurs in early adolescence. This condition is caused due to twisting of the blood supply of the testes and the spermatic cord as depicted in the image below.

Patients commonly present with sudden-onset scrotal pain. The testes might also be swollen and tender.

Testicular torsion is an emergency and surgical detorsion along with testicular fixation/orchidopexy is done in these patients.

questions.text: A young female patient was brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. She was hemodynamically stable and her Glasgow coma scale score was 3. She was intubated and sent for non-contrast CT which was found to be normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of diffuse axonal injury.

Diffuse axonal injury (white matter shearing) is the result of shearing forces, typically from a rotational acceleration of the brain within the rigid cranium.

This causes damage to microvasculature and disruption of axons in the subcortical parasagittal white matter, cerebellum, fornix, and internal and external capsule.

Most commonly it occurs in automobile accidents. Patients are usually unconscious from the moment of impact and remain the same until death.

Diffuse axonal injury is characterized by multiple focal lesions with a characteristic distribution:

  • CT may be normal.
  • MRI is the modality of choice for assessing suspected diffuse axonal injury even in patients with entirely normal CT of the brain.
  • MRI, especially SWI (susceptibility-weighted imaging) demonstrates small regions of susceptibility artifact or hemorrhage.

Option A- Subdural hemorrhage is often due to the rupture of veins that crosses the subdural space. In subdural hemorrhage, the CT shows concavo-convex opacity. 

Option B- Extradural hemorrhage is mostly due to the rupture of the middle meningeal artery. Since the dura matter tends to adhere to the skull the hemorrhage is seen in CT as a biconvex dense area. They usually do not cross cranial sutures.

Option D: Cerebral contusion occurs due to traumatic brain injury, at the sites that come in direct contact with the skull. Imaging may show microhemorrhages and edema. Usually, no treatment is required.

questions.text: Identify the pathology in the given radiograph of a newborn.
questions.solution:
The given radiograph of a newborn shows imperforate anus/anal atresia. 

Anorectal atresia, also known as imperforate anus, refers to a spectrum of abnormalities of the rectum and anus. Incidence is one in every 5,000 live birth.

This disease is commonly associated with a group of congenital anomalies. These anomalies are called VACTRL and they are comprised of:

  • Vertebral defects
  • Anal defects
  • Cardiac defects
  • Tracheoesophageal fistula
  • Renal defects
  • Limb defects 

Children affected with this condition present with failure to pass meconium and abdominal distension.

The above radiograph is a lateral film taken with the child in a prone position. This is used to assess the level of atresia. If the distance between the distal air bubble and the lead probe is greater than 1 cm it indicates a high defect. Conversely, if the distance between these two points is less than 1 cm it indicates a low defect.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient came to the hospital for medical termination of pregnancy. From whom will you obtain consent for the procedure?
questions.solution:
Only the patient's consent is required for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) and her male partner's consent is not required.

Consent of parent/guardian is needed if the age of the patient is <18 yrs or if the patient is mentally ill.

Related Pearl: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

  • Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother
  • Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure
  • Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest
  • Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text: A female patient who underwent dilatation and curettage following a missed abortion now presents with amenorrhoea. The urine pregnancy test is negative. Hysterosalpingography shows the findings seen in the image below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history along with the presence of multiple, linear, irregular filling defects on hysterosalpingography suggests a diagnosis of Asherman syndrome.

Asherman syndrome is a condition characterized by the presence of scar tissue in the endometrial cavity.

It refers to the presence of uterine synechiae, due to the destruction of the endometrium. It can occur as a result of trauma to the endometrium following vigorous curettages for elective abortion, tuberculous endometritis, and uterine surgeries.

Patients present with features such as oligomenorrhoea, amenorrhoea, dysmenorrhoea, and synechiae due to uterine adhesions.

The following factors predispose a patient to develop Asherman syndrome:

  • Vigorous curettage following postpartum hemorrhage or abortion
  • Genital tuberculosis
  • Schistosomiasis

Hysterosalpingography is performed to assess the uterine cavity and tubal patency. Intrauterine adhesions are characteristically seen as irregular angulated filling defects in the uterine cavity with a classic 'moth-eaten' appearance. 

Definitive diagnosis (gold standard) and management are done by hysteroscopy. Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis is the surgical treatment of choice.

Hormonal assays also aid in the diagnosis of anatomical causes of amenorrhea such as Asherman syndrome. All women with amenorrhea in the reproductive age group are considered pregnant unless proven otherwise by negative urinary or serum β-HCG levels. Once negative for pregnancy, further testing is done by a progesterone challenge test.

This test is done by administering medroxyprogesterone acetate as a 10-mg daily oral dose for 10 days. If the woman bleeds, then she is assumed to produce estrogen and to have a developed endometrium, and the presence of a patent outflow tract is confirmed. If she does not bleed, then she is given estrogen followed by progesterone treatment in the form of combined OCPs. If she fails to bleed after completing the 21 hormone-containing pills, then an anatomic abnormality is diagnosed such as Asherman syndrome.

questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is a hydatidiform mole.

Patients present with vaginal bleeding following 1-2 months of amenorrhea. The blood may be mixed with gelatinous fluid from ruptured cysts. Advanced cases may have nausea, vomiting, hyperthyroidism, and iron deficiency anemia.

On ultrasound, these patients demonstrate a characteristic snowstorm appearance. Management of this condition involves termination of the pregnancy followed by regular monitoring of beta HCG levels.

questions.text: A patient who stopped alcohol consumption 48 hours back presented with irritability, tremors, disorientation, agitation, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium. His heart rate is 160 beats per minute and his blood pressure is 170/80 mm of Hg. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient who has not consumed alcohol for the past 48 hours presenting with disorientation, agitation, visual hallucinations, altered sensorium, tachycardia, and elevated blood pressure is suggestive of delirium tremens.

Delirium tremens is the most severe form of alcohol withdrawal. It is an acute condition and usually develops 48-72 hours after the last drink. It is characterized by symptoms such as:

  • Extreme mental confusion
  • Agitation
  • Tremors
  • Autonomic hyperactivity with tachycardia, fever, anxiety, sweating, insomnia, and hypertension

Other options:

Option B - Wernicke’s encephalopathy (alcoholic encephalopathy) is associated with thiamine deficiency. It is associated with a triad of confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia.

Option C - Korsakoff’s psychosis can follow Wernicke’s encephalopathy due to thiamine deficiency. It is associated with anterograde and retrograde amnesia. Confabulation is a classic sign.

Option D - Alcoholic hallucinosis occurs during heavy drinking or withdrawal and is characterized by paranoid psychosis without other symptoms such as tremulousness, confusion, and altered sensorium.

questions.text: A young female patient presents with irregular periods. Her ultrasound scan revealed the finding shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is polycystic ovarian disease(PCOD).

Polycystic ovarian disease is a disease characterized by menstrual abnormalities and hyperandrogenism in women of reproductive age.

This condition has been linked with risk factors such as obesity and insulin resistance.

Clinically these patients present with infertility and features of hyperandrogenism such as hirsutism and acne.

On ultrasound, these patients have larger ovaries with an increased number of follicles. Multiple follicles that are peripherally located in the ovary can be seen on ultrasound. This is also called the string of pearls sign.

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone >2 ng/mL, free T >2.2 pg/mL (Normal level 0.2–0.8 ng/mL)
    • Normal androstenedione level is 1.3–1.5 ng/mL
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

questions.text: A young patient presents to the outpatient department with complaints of chronic scaly plaques over the extensor surface associated with pruritus. On examination, the patient's nails demonstrate subungual hyperkeratosis and distal onycholysis as shown in the image. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is psoriasis. The pruritic scaly lesions, onycholysis, and subungual hyperkeratosis are nail findings seen in patients with psoriasis.

Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the skin with systemic manifestations. Patients commonly present with red, scaly plaques over the extensor surfaces and the scalp, associated with pruritus.

Nail findings are commonly seen across all types of psoriasis. Patients present with pits, ridges, and grooves of the nail plate. In the case of nail bed involvement subungual oil drops, subungual hyperkeratosis, and distal onycholysis can be seen.

Other options:

Option A - Lichen planus is an inflammatory disorder affecting the skin and mucosal membranes. Nail involvement includes exaggeration of the longitudinal lines and linear depression. This is due to nail plate thinning. If the nail bed is involved, it can result in hyperpigmentation, subungual hyperkeratosis, and onycholysis. In some cases, pterygium unguis can be seen due to adhesion between the dorsal nail fold and the nail bed.

Option C - Atopic dermatitis presents with itchy erythematous papules/papulo-vesicles in flexural regions. Patients usually have a history of other autoimmune diseases.

Option D - Alopecia areata is a condition that results in non-scarring hair loss. It can cause fine stippled pitting of the nails, roughening of the nail plate (trachyonychia), or atrophic dystrophy.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

questions.solution:

questions.text: Which of the following protocols set the standard to reduce the emission of greenhouse gases internationally?
questions.solution:
The Kyoto Protocol was an internal agreement to set internationally binding emission reduction targets.

It is linked to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. The parties committed to reduce GHGs by 18% in the period between 2013-2020.

Related Pearl: Greenhouse Effect

  • Certain gases in the atmosphere absorb some of the upward-going, long-wave radiation after it has left the Earth’s surface
  • These gases are known as greenhouse gases (GHGs) or radiatively active gases (RAGs)
  • These gases then emit longwave radiation in all directions, the downward going portion of which add to the radiation arriving at the Earth’s surface and raise the equilibrium temperature.
  • In this entire process, the Earth acts as an effective insulator and the overall process is known as Greenhouse effect.
  • The most important natural GHGs are water vapour, carbon dioxide, methane, tropospheric ozone and nitrous oxide and non-natural GHGs are chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs).
  • Stratospheric ozone is not harmful and doesn’t contribute to the greenhouse effect
  • Greenhouse effect has a role in global warming which is the average rise in global temperature leading to change in climate patterns.
  • The Kyoto Protocol is an internal agreement linked to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change by which its Parties set internationally binding emission reduction targets. The Parties committed to reduce GHGs by 18 percent in period between 2013 and 2020.
  • The Paris Agreement central aim is to strengthen the global response to the threat of climate change by keeping a global temperature rise this century well below 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels and to pursue efforts to limit the temperature increase even further to 1.5 degrees Celsius. It deals with greenhouse gas emissions mitigation, apdaptation and finance starting in the year 2020.
  • The Montreal Protocol is related to the depletion of the atmospheric ozone layer, which is protective.

questions.text: Pressure greater than __ mm of Hg causes pressure sores.
questions.solution:
Pressure sores are tissue necrosis with ulceration due to continuous pressure. This condition usually develops if the external pressure is greater than 30 mm of Hg.

This condition is commonly seen in patients who are not ambulatory and chronically hospitalized. A bedridden patient must be turned every two hours to prevent them from developing pressure sores.

Surgical management of pressure sores is the same as that of general wound care and encompasses good nutrition, adequate debridement, and vacuum-assisted closure if indicated.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the casualty with confusion, vomiting, and abdominal pain. His blood sugar levels are 421 mg/dl and his urine ketones are 3+. He is started on IV normal saline and insulin infusion. Which of the following electrolyte abnormality should he be monitored for?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis, which is treated with insulin infusion. Patients with diabetic ketoacidosis are at risk for developing hypokalemia after the initiation of treatment.

Diabetic ketoacidosis(DKA) is a life-threatening condition characterized by elevated blood sugar levels and ketosis. Patients present with symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, confusion, and abdominal pain.

DKA is managed with a combination of intravenous fluids, insulin, and potassium correction.

At presentation, these patients have normal to high potassium levels in spite of excessive potassium loss. This is because potassium moves out from the cell to the extracellular space as a result of acidosis.

Once insulin is administered and acidosis is corrected, the potassium ion flows back into the cells causing hypokalemia. Hence the physician should be vigilant and initiate intravenous potassium correction once insulin is given to the patient.

questions.text: A man was working at a construction site on a hot summer afternoon when he suddenly collapsed. His coworkers said there was no history of sweating. On examination, the patient was tachycardic, tachypneic, and hypotensive. The doctor found that the rectal temperature was 42ºC.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is heat stroke.

Heat stroke is a life-threatening condition occurring due to cerebral dysfunction when the core temperature is over 40 degrees celsius.

Classic heat stroke occurs in patients with impaired thermoregulation or those that are exposed to extreme environmental conditions. 

Exertional heat stroke occurs in healthy persons taking part in strenuous physical activity in a hot or humid environment.

Patients present with abnormalities such as tachycardia, tachypnea, hypotension, and widened pulse pressure. In certain cases, patients may also exhibit premonitory psychiatry symptoms and ataxia.

Other options:

Option A: Heat cramps are painful skeletal muscle spasms that occur during or immediately after exercise.

Option B: Heat syncope is a transient loss of consciousness in patients who have been standing for a long duration in a hot or humid environment.

questions.text: A middle age male patient with a long history of poorly controlled hypertension presents for a follow-up. The physician prescribes a doppler ultrasonography which reveals severe stenosis of the right renal artery due to atherosclerosis. Which of the following drugs is recommended for managing this patient?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is unilateral renal artery stenosis. Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors(ACEi) such as enalapril are used in the management of patients with unilateral renal artery stenosis.

Patients with renal artery stenosis present with refractory/new-onset hypertension. Physical examination may reveal an audible bruit on the affected side in these patients. Doppler ultrasonography or CT angiography can be used to confirm a diagnosis of renal artery stenosis. Renal angiography is the gold standard investigation.

Treatment options are:

  • Medical management with ACEi
  • Angioplasty with or without stenting
  • Surgical bypass

ACE inhibitors can cause angioedema in a small group which presents as swelling of the throat, mouth, tongue, and glottis. It is usually self-limiting once the drug is discontinued. Other adverse effects include hypotension, dry cough, hyperkalemia, and skin rashes. In patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis, it can precipitate acute renal failure and hence contraindicated.

questions.text: A newborn is seen to have an abnormal lump in the lower back. Identify the condition from the MRI given below.
questions.solution:
The MRI demonstrates meningocele.

Meningocele is formed when meninges herniate through a defect in the posterior vertebral arches. Patients present with a fluctuant midline mass that is covered with skin. Transillumination through the swelling may be present.

Other options:

Option B: Myelomeningocele is a severe form of incomplete fusion of the vertebral column. Meninges and spinal cord herniate through the gap. Patients commonly present with a lumbosacral defect covered by a thin layer of epithelialized tissue. It is associated with flaccid paralysis of lower limbs.

Option C: Spina bifida occulta is a midline defect of the vertebral bodies without protrusion of the spinal cord or meninges.

Option D: Lissencephaly is a disorder characterized by a lack of cerebral convolutions.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the emergency department because of an episode of seizure. The seizure was preceded by a history of high fever over the past 24 hours. Kernig’s sign is negative and there are no post-ictal neurological deficits. The child had a similar episode when he was diagnosed with chicken pox at the age of 2 years. Which of the following is false regarding this type of seizure?

choices.text: Likelihood of developing epilepsy is low
Associated with temperature of 38°C or higher
Antipyretics reduce the risk of recurrent febrile convulsions
There is no associated developmental delay

questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is febrile seizures. Antipyretics do not decrease the risk of recurrent febrile seizures.

Febrile seizures are seizures associated with high-grade fever (>38 degrees celsius) occurring in children with no neurological abnormalities between 6 months and 5 years of age

Types of febrile seizures:

No recurrence within 24 hrs of seizures Recurrent

Lumbar puncture should be performed in the first episode of seizures with fever, for all infants <6 months of age (to exclude meningitis). EEG and neuroimaging are advised for children with atypical febrile seizures. 

Diazepam, midazolam, and antipyretics are employed in the management of febrile seizures.

questions.text: A young primigravida presents with painless vaginal bleeding in the first trimester. On examination, the cervical os is closed and uterine size is normal. The gestational sac is visible on ultrasound. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of threatened abortion. 

Threatened abortion is defined as bleeding through a closed cervical os in the first 20 weeks of pregnancy, with a live fetus.

The patient presents with a bloody vaginal discharge or bleeding through a closed cervical os. On ultrasound, the gestational sac can be visible. In about two-thirds of the cases, pregnancy continues beyond 28 weeks.

Treatment:

  • Analgesics if there is pain
  • Progesterone has been shown to improve outcomes in certain patients

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman who has regular menstrual cycles presents with amenorrhea. A urine pregnancy test is done and found to be positive. She recalls that the first day of her last menstrual period was October 9 2022. What would her expected date of delivery be based on Naegele's rule?
questions.solution:
Based on Naegele’s rule, the expected date of delivery (EDD) of this patient is July 16th 2023.

Naegele’s rule is based on a 28-day regular cycle and states that the EDD is obtained by adding 7 days and subtracting 3 months from the 1st day of the last menstrual period (LMP). Another method is adding 9 months and 7 days to the 1st day of the LMP.

questions.text: A 7-month-old child is brought to the outpatient department with a deformity as shown in the image given below. Which of the following is the preferred first-line conservative management?
questions.solution:
The first line of conservative management of the condition in the given image, congenital talipes equino varus deformity (CTEV), is manipulation and cast by Ponsetti's method.

CTEV is a congenital deformity of the foot. In a full-blown deformity, the foot is in equinus, the entire hindfoot is in varus and the mid and forefoot are adducted and supinated. Clinically this appears as a foot that's twisted and turned inwards.

In patients with CTEV, the skin and soft tissues of the calf and the medial side of the foot are underdeveloped. If CTEV is not managed appropriately then these changes become permanent.

The first line of conservative management in a child with CTEV is Ponsetti's method. In this method, the three main deformities of CTEV are collected in the following order.

  • Cavus - The first metatarsal is elevated to create a flat longitudinal medial border of the foot.
  • Adduction- The forefoot is abducted in the plane of the metatarsals which rotates and everts the hindfoot and corrects the forefoot out of supination
  • Equinus is corrected by dorsiflexing the foot at the ankle joint. 

Related Pearl: Age wise management of CTEV

Initial treatment starts with Ponseti's POP cast as early as possible, but within 1 year of age.

If deformity gets corrected:

  • Dennis Brown splint is used till 1 year of age
  • After 1 year upto 5 years CTEV shoes are used in day, and Dennis Brown splint is used at night

If deformity is not corrected or untreated previously:

  • 3-5 years: Dillwyn Evans procedure
  • 5-8 years: Dwyer osteotomy
  • 8-10 years: Wedge tarsectomy
  • >10 years: Triple arthrodesis, external fixators

questions.text: A young girl presented to the outpatient department with pallor of extremities, pain, and cyanosis on exposure to cold. This phenomenon is commonly associated with which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
The patient in the above clinical scenario is likely describing Raynaud's phenomenon. Raynaud's phenomenon is usually an initial manifestation of scleroderma.

Raynaud phenomenon presents as episodic vasoconstriction of the arteries and arterioles of the extremities, causing pallor of extremities followed by pain and cyanosis. It is seen in virtually all patients with systemic sclerosis or scleroderma and precedes other symptoms in most cases.

The image shows features of Raynaud's phenomenon.

Systemic sclerosis is characterized by progressive fibrosis involving the skin and internal organs. Two forms of this disease are limited and diffuse. Limited systemic sclerosis is also associated with one or more features of CREST syndrome. CREST syndrome is:

  • Raynaud phenomenon

questions.text: A child is brought to the outpatient department with the following karyotyping image. What are the clinical features most likely to be expected in such children?
questions.solution:
The given karyotyping image shows 47, XXY abnormality, which is seen in Klinefelter syndrome. Gynecomastia and long limbs are seen in this condition.

Klinefelter's syndrome is a sex chromosome abnormality and is the most common cause of infertility and hypogonadism in males.

Other clinical features seen in Klinefelter’s syndrome are: 

  • Tall stature and long limbs
  • Small atrophic testis and small penis
  • Lack of secondary sexual characteristics (due to a decrease in androgen production)
  • Gynecomastia
  • Minor developmental and learning disabilities,
  • Higher risk of breast carcinoma and extragonadal germ cell tumors
  • Type 2 diabetes mellitus

questions.text: An infant is brought to the pediatric outpatient department with seizures, intellectual disability, and subependymal nodules on the MRI brain. On examination, the following cutaneous lesion is seen. Name the lesion.
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of tuberous sclerosis and the image shows ash leaf macules seen in this condition.

Tuberous sclerosis is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous disorder characterized by the presence of benign congenital tumors in multiple organs. The mutations are involved in the TSC1 gene that encodes hamartin on chromosome 9 and the TSC2 gene that encodes a protein tuberin on chromosome 16. Loss-of-function mutations of these tumour suppressor genes (TSC1&2) are present. It presents during childhood with intellectual disability, skin lesions, and seizures. On brain MRI, subependymal nodules can be seen.

The clinical features include seizures, intellectual disability, white ovoid or ash‐leaf‐shaped macules 1–3 cm in length, most easily detectable by examination under Wood’s light, are frequently present on the trunk or limbs. Adenoma sebaceum (facial angiofibromas), a shagreen patch is an irregularly thickened, slightly elevated, soft, skin‐coloured plaque, usually in the lumbosacral region. Periungual fibromas and renal angiomyolipomas

Facial angiofibromas(Option A) - reddish nodules seen on the nose and cheeks. Eventually, they join together to form a fleshy growth. It is shown in the image given below:

Periungual fibromas - They are small fibromas or skin nodules seen around fingers or toenails in a few patients. The image below shows these lesions:

A Shagreen patch(Option D) is a rough, raised lesion commonly seen in the lumbosacral region.

questions.text: A young male patient was brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident with complaints of breathing difficulty. On examination, his BP was 80/40mmHg and pulses were feeble, jugular venous pulse was found to be elevated with a prominent x descent and an absent y descent. While recording the patient's blood pressure, a significant drop in systolic pressure during inspiration is noted. Auscultation revealed absent heart sounds. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is cardiac tamponade.

Cardiac tamponade is a condition caused to accumulation of the fluid in the pericardial space causing significant obstruction to the inflow of blood into the cardiac ventricles.

The most common causes of tamponade are pericarditis, tuberculosis, and bleeding into the pericardial space secondary to trauma/cardiac surgery.

The three main features associated with cardiac tamponade are hypotension, soft or absent heart sounds, and jugular venous distension. These features constitute Beck's triad. 

Jugular venous pulse(JVP) demonstrates a prominent x descent but an absent y descent.

Paradoxical pulse is another feature seen in patients with cardiac tamponade and is characterized by a significant decline (>10 mm Hg) in arterial pressure during inspiration.

Other options:

  • While constrictive pericarditis can also lead to elevated jugular venous pressure, it typically does not cause the classic physical findings associated with cardiac tamponade, such as pulsus paradoxus (significant drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration) and the absence of heart sounds. Patients with constrictive pericarditis (option A) demonstrate a prominent y descent.
  • The physical exam findings in this case, including elevated jugular venous pressure and pulsus paradoxus, are not typically associated with a myocardial infarction. Additionally, absent heart sounds are not a characteristic finding of myocardial infarction.
  • While heart failure can result in elevated jugular venous pressure, the physical exam findings, including pulsus paradoxus, absent heart sounds, and prominent x descent with an absent y descent, are not specific to cardiac failure and are more indicative of cardiac tamponade in this context.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient with a history of chronic alcoholism comes to the clinic with ascites and icterus. He is diagnosed with alcoholic liver disease leading to portal hypertension. Which type of portal hypertension is most likely in this patient?

questions.text: A young lactating mother presents with pain in her left breast and a fever. On examination of the affected side, there is localized erythema, warmth, point tenderness, and fluctuation test is positive. Repeated aspirations under antibiotic cover were unsuccessful. A USG done showed fluid collection. How will this patient be managed?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario points towards a diagnosis of breast abscess. The next best step in the management of this patient would be incision and drainage of the abscess.

Breast abscess occurs as a complication of bacterial mastitis. Bacterial mastitis is a common variety of mastitis and is associated with lactation.

Initially, patients may present with signs of acute inflammation in the affected area. Later as the disease progresses, signs of an abscess such as a palpable mass or an area of fluctuance may be present. Additional symptoms such as point tenderness, erythema, and hyperthermia are also seen in the case of breast abscess.

Management includes analgesia, antibiotics such as amoxiclav, and repeated aspiration of pus. In case of failure of aspiration and antibiotics, incision and drainage can be done.

questions.text: The following Indices are used for measuring disability except
questions.solution:
PQLI includes infant mortality rate, literacy, and life expectancy at 1 year whereas other indicators are directly related to the measurement of disability.

 Sullivan's index is also known as disability-free life expectancy (DFLE) or active life expectancy. It is the average number of years an individual is expected to live free of disability if the current patterns of mortality and disability continue to apply. It doesn’t take into account premature death.
Disability-free life expectancy = (Life expectancy) - (the duration of the disability).

DALY is the best measure of the overall burden of a disease in a defined population and the effectiveness of interventions. It can measure both mortality and disability together.
DALY = Years of lost life (YLL) + Years lost of disability (YLD)

HALE (Health Adjusted Life Expectancy) is an indicator that can be used to estimate the number of years a newborn is expected to live in full health based on the current rates of ill health and mortality. HALE is calculated using the life expectancy at birth with an adjustment for time spent in poor health. It captures both fatal and non-fatal health outcomes of average levels of population health. It is also sensitive to changes over time or differences between countries in the distribution of health states.

questions.text: A young female patient presented with a complaint of a palpable painless mass in the left breast. On examination, the mass was highly mobile, firm, and rubbery in consistency. Ultrasound of the left breast was performed and the finding is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is fibroadenoma of the breast.

Fibroadenoma is a benign tumor of the breast. It is commonly seen in women between the age of 14-35. Patients present with a unilateral, painless breast lump that is mobile, firm, and rubbery in consistency with well-defined borders.

On ultrasound, a well-circumscribed mass of uniform hypoechogenicity is seen.

Management is usually conservative since this tumor shrinks over time. In the case of rapidly enlarging fibroadenomas, lumpectomy might be considered.

The given image represents a septate hymen.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with symptoms of fatigue and headache. On further examination, he is found to have pallor, tingling, and numbness over his extremities. Peripheral smear shows macrocytic anemia. Laboratory findings revealed methylmalonic acid excretion in the urine. He was diagnosed with type II diabetes 15 years ago and has been taking metformin. Which of the following is most likely deficient in him?
questions.solution:
A vitamin B12/cobalamin deficiency is most likely seen in him.

The given clinical features of peripheral neuropathy, peripheral smear finding of macrocytic anemia with hypersegmented neutrophils, methylmalonic acid excretion in the urine, and history of metformin intake after being diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus indicate a vitamin B12 deficiency.

Vitamin B12 or cobalamin is a water-soluble vitamin that is derived from animal products such as red meat, dairy, and eggs. Its absorption in the terminal ileum is facilitated by the presence of intrinsic factor, produced by parietal cells in the stomach. There are two vitamin B12-dependent enzymes:

  • Methionine synthase (homocysteine methyltransferase): Catalyzes the conversion of homocysteine to methionine.
  • Methylmalonyl CoA mutase: methylmalonyl CoA, formed as an intermediate in the catabolism of valine, isoleucine, and propionyl CoA is converted to succinyl CoA.

The activity of methylmalonyl CoA mutase is greatly reduced in vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to an accumulation of methylmalonic acid and its excretion in urine. Since vitamin B12 is also linked to the regeneration of methionine from homocysteine, its deficiency can result in hyperhomocysteinemia as well.

Risk factors for B12 deficiency include gastric atrophy (pernicious anemia), terminal ileal disease, strict vegetarianism, acid-reducing drugs (e.g., H2 blockers), and prolonged use of metformin. The interference by metformin on calcium-dependent membrane action is responsible for vitamin B12-intrinsic factor malabsorption in the terminal ileum.

On examination, patients present anemia, fatigue, and pallor symptoms. Other presenting complaints may include peripheral neuropathy, glossitis, diarrhea, headaches, neuropsychiatric disturbances like dementia, and subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord(SACD) leading to ataxia. A peripheral smear shows macrocytic anemia and hypersegmented neutrophils.

Other options:

Option A: Vitamin B9(Folic acid) deficiency can also be seen in patients on prolonged use of metformin and can cause macrocytic anemia. Urinary excretion of methylmalonic acid differentiates between megaloblastic anemia due to folate and vitamin B12 deficiency. Folate deficiency results in:

  • Megaloblastic anemia 
  • Homocystenemia
  • Neural tube defects (spina bifida, Anencephaly) in the fetus.

Option C: A patient with pyridoxine / Vitamin B6 deficiency presents with symptoms of seborrhea, glossitis, convulsions, neuropathy, depression, confusion, and microcytic anemia.

Option D: A patient with thiamine / Vitamin B1 deficiency presents either dry Beriberi with predominantly neurological symptoms like neuropathy, muscle weakness and wasting or wet Beriberi with predominant cardiac symptoms like cardiomegaly, tachycardia, high output congestive cardiac failure.

questions.text: A middle age male patient presented with complaints of palpitations. The patient's ECG tracing is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient with ECG showing irregularly irregular rhythm is atrial fibrillation.

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a type of cardiac arrhythmia characterized by disorganized, rapid, and irregular atrial activation. It is common in men and risk factors are age, underlying cardiac disease, hypertension, diabetes, family history of AF, and obesity.

Features include heart rate typically ranging from 110-160 beats/minute. It is irregular and rapid. Presyncope and syncope can be seen. Thrombus formation can occur and thromboembolic events can take place.

Typically, ECG shows an irregularly irregular rhythm with absent p waves.

Management is mainly by controlling rate and rhythm, avoiding the thromboembolism risk and modifying risk factors.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient comes to the psychiatry outpatient department with complaints of low mood, difficulty falling asleep, lack of appetite, lack of energy, and recurring thoughts of death for the past 4 weeks. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The possible diagnosis in a patient with complaints of low mood, difficulty falling asleep, lack of appetite, lack of energy, and recurring thoughts of death for a period of 4 weeks is a major depressive disorder. 

Major depressive disorder is a mood disorder characterized by pervasive low mood without manic or hypomanic episodes. A major depressive episode lasts for at least two weeks and the patient experiences at least 4 of the following symptoms:

  • Feeling depressed/low mood for most of the day
  • Changes in appetite
  • Changes in weight
  • Changes in sleep
  • Changes in activity level
  • Lack of energy
  • Feelings of guilt
  • Recurring thoughts of death/suicidal thoughts

These symptoms usually cause significant impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

Other options:

Option A: Conversion disorder is a condition with symptoms or deficits that involve voluntary motor or sensory functions. Though it points to an underlying medical condition, in reality, it arises due to psychological factors. The symptoms are not intentionally produced. Paralysis, blindness, and mutism are the most frequently seen conversion disorder symptoms. 

Option B: Somatic symptom disorder is characterized by the fear of having a serious illness based on the person's misinterpretation of bodily symptoms. The symptoms are persistent for over 6 months. 

Option C:  Dysthymic disorder is the presence of a persistently depressed mood that lasts most of the day and is continuous. There are also feelings of guilt, irritability, and anger associated with it. These symptoms are present for at least 2 years.

questions.text: A young male patient with a history of a respiratory tract infection 4 weeks ago presents with progressively increasing weakness and tingling of bilateral lower limbs. His upper limbs are not affected and on examination, there is an absent knee jerk. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is Guillain Barre (GB) syndrome.

Guillain-Barre syndrome is an autoimmune disorder characterized by ascending motor paralysis. Patients present with symptoms such as:

  • Progressive ascending motor paralysis
  • Areflexia. Deep tendon reflexes disappear within the first few days of symptoms
  • Tingling sensation
  • Facial paresis may be seen in certain cases

It is estimated that 70% of cases of GB syndrome occur following an acute infection, usually respiratory or gastrointestinal.

High-dose intravenous immune globulin (IVIg) or plasmapheresis are equally effective for typical GBS. IVIg is the initial therapy chosen because of its ease of administration and good safety record.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of Immunopathogenesis of Guillain-Barre Syndrome

The following sequence of events, takes into consideration, the development of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) associated with Campylobacter jejuni infection.

  1. B cells recognize glycoconjugates on jejuni (Cj) that cross-react with ganglioside present on Schwann cell surface and subjacent peripheral nerve myelin.
  2. Most of the B cells are activated via a partially T cell–dependent route and secrete primarily IgG autoantibodies. Some B cells, activated via a T cell–independent mechanism, secrete primarily IgM
  3. The activated B cells escape from Peyer’s patches into regional lymph nodes.
  4. Activated T cells also function to assist in the opening of the blood-nerve barrier, facilitating penetration of pathogenic autoantibodies.
  5. The earliest changes in myelin consist of edema between myelin lamellae and vesicular disruption of the outermost myelin layers.
  6. These effects are associated with activation of the C5b-C9 membrane attack complex and mediated by calcium entry; it is possible that the macrophage cytokine tumor necrosis factor (TNF) also participates in myelin damage.

questions.text: A young infant with cyanotic heart disease presents with the following radiograph. Which of the following is not a component of this patient's disease?
questions.solution:
In a child with cyanotic heart disease and a plain radiograph showing a boot-shaped heart, the likely diagnosis is tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). An atrial septal defect is not a component of TOF.

Tetralogy of Fallot is cyanotic congenital heart disease with four classical anatomical features. These features are:

  • Severe right ventricular outflow obstruction
  • Ventricular septal defect
  • An aorta that overrides the ventricular septal defect
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy

Patients present with symptoms such as cyanosis, dyspnea on exertion, and anoxic spells.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient presents with sudden palpitations, sweating, breathlessness, intense fear, and a feeling like she is being choked. questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient presents to the OPD with complaints of shortness of breath and tiredness for weeks. On examination, there were engorged neck veins and jugular venous pressure showed prominent x and y descent. The chest radiograph is seen below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and X-ray showing calcification of the pericardium are suggestive of constrictive pericarditis.

Constrictive pericarditis is a condition in which granulation tissue formation in the pericardium results in loss of pericardial elasticity leading to restricted ventricular filling. It is usually a chronic condition.

The leading cause worldwide is tuberculosis. Other common causes include viral infections, SLE and idiopathic. Patients who have undergone cardiac surgery or radiation therapy are also at an increased risk of developing this condition.

Clinically patients present with symptoms such as dyspnea, orthopnea and fatigue. On physical examination, the jugular venous pressure (JVP) is usually elevated with a prominent x and y descent. JVP does not decrease with inspiration, and this is known as Kussmaul's sign. 

ECHO is used to make a diagnosis and patients may demonstrate pericardial calcification on chest radiographs. Pericardiectomy is the only definitive management.

questions.text: A female patient, who is 6 months postpartum, presented with complaints of feeling low, anhedonia, and suicidal ideation since childbirth. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Postpartum depression is the most likely diagnosis in a postpartum woman with complaints of feeling low, anhedonia, and suicidal ideation. In such a patient, SSRIs such as Fluoxetine and Paroxetine are the preferred first-line drugs.

Postpartum depression falls under the ambit of postpartum mood disorders. Disorders such as postpartum blues and postpartum psychosis also fall under this category.

Postpartum depression occurs at least 4-6 months after childbirth or an abortion. It is characterized by symptoms such as loss of energy and appetite, insomnia, anhedonia, and in some cases, suicidal ideations.

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors such as Fluoxetine and Paroxetine are preferred since they are effective and have fewer side effects. These drugs are also safe during breastfeeding.

Other options

Option A: Reassurance would be an appropriate next step in case the patient is suffering from postpartum blues.

Option C: Chlorpromazine is a first-generation antipsychotic that is used in the management of postpartum psychosis

Option D: Lorazepam belongs to a class of drugs known as benzodiazepines that have no role in the management of postpartum mood disorders.

questions.text: A young female patient presented at 7 weeks of gestation, unwilling to continue the pregnancy. What are the drugs used for the medical termination of pregnancy in this patient?
questions.solution:
The drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) in this patient presenting at 7 weeks of gestation are misoprostol and mifepristone. 

Mifepristone 200mg is administered orally on day 1. The minimum recommended interval between mifepristone & misoprostol is 24 hours. This is followed by 800 mcg of misoprostol given via the vaginal, sublingual, or buccal route.

The patient is asked to report after 15 days to evaluate for completeness of the abortion.

Related Pearl: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

  • Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother
  • Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure
  • Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest
  • Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text: Gleason score is used to grade tumors of which of the following organ
questions.solution:
The Gleason score is used to grade carcinoma of the prostate.

Since malignancies of the prostate exhibit heterogenic features within the tissue, two histologically separate areas of the gland are scored between 1-5. These scores are added to give an overall Gleason score of 2-10.

This score is used to assess the likelihood of spread and prognosis of prostate carcinoma.

questions.text: A patient in the ward has been diagnosed with bacterial meningitis. Which of the following antimicrobials can be used empirically in this patient?
questions.solution:
In a patient with bacterial meningitis, third or fourth-generation cephalosporins such as ceftriaxone, cefotaxime, or cefepime are used empirically.

Bacterial meningitis is a medical emergency and treatment should be initiated within 60 minutes of a patient's arrival at the emergency department.

Empirical therapy of community-acquired bacterial meningitis in adults should include a combination of drugs such as dexamethasone, a third or fourth-generation cephalosporin, vancomycin, and acyclovir. 

Penicillin G is the drug of choice in patients with meningococcal meningitis caused by susceptible strains.

questions.text: Preconceptional use of which of the following leads to decreased incidence of neural tube defects?
questions.solution:
Pre-conceptional use of folic acid reduces the incidence of neural tube defects.

Folic acid deficiency is implicated in neural tube defects like spina bifida, encephalocele, and anencephaly.

Pregnant women are advised 60 mg of iron and 400 mcg of folic acid every day till term and during lactation for 3 months

questions.text: A middle-aged retroviral positive patient presents with a productive cough associated with blood-stained sputum, evening rise in temperature, and weight loss for 3 weeks. His chest radiograph is shown in the image below.  What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is pulmonary tuberculosis.

Pulmonary tuberculosis is an infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Patients present with symptoms such as malaise, anorexia, fever, evening rise in temperatures, night sweats, weight loss, cough with expectoration, and hemoptysis. The incidence of this disease is higher in patients who have been diagnosed with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS).

On chest radiographs, these patients exhibit upper lobe consolidation with hilar lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: An elderly male patient presented with easy fatiguability, and backache. He gives a history of recurrent infections in the past 3 months. Laboratory reports showed hypercalcemia. His skull radiograph is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is multiple myeloma.

Multiple myeloma is a disease characterized by the malignant proliferation of plasma cells. Patients present with features such as bone pain, renal failure, susceptibility to infections, anemia, and hypercalcemia.

The plain radiograph of this patient's skull demonstrates several punched-out lytic lesions, which are characteristic of multiple myeloma.

questions.text: A young sexually active female patient presented to the outpatient department with complaints of lower abdominal pain, fever, vomiting, foul-smelling vaginal discharge, and dysuria. On examination, the body temperature is 103 degrees Fahrenheit, pulse rate is 109 per minute and there is abdominal tenderness. Which of the following are long-term sequela of this condition?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is pelvic inflammatory disease(PID) and infertility is a long-term sequela of this condition.

Pelvic inflammatory disease is characterized by inflammation of the upper genital tract including the fallopian tubes as well as the ovaries.

This disease is commonly seen in sexually active young women and is usually preceded by a sexually transmitted disease. Gonococcal and chlamydial infections are commonly associated with PID.

Patients present with lower abdominal pain, fever, vomiting, dysuria, and vaginal discharge. The symptoms also vary depending on the causative organism. On examination, there is a fever of around 103- 104°F, abdominal tenderness, tachycardia, and pelvic mass.

Chronic PID is associated with sequelae such as chronic pelvic pain, menorrhagia, ectopic pregnancy, and infertility.

questions.text: A young patient presents to you with the following finding. What is the nerve affected?
questions.solution:
The given image shows is that of a claw hand classically seen in case of an ulnar nerve injury.

The ulnar nerve supplies the medial two lumbricals, adductor pollicis, interossei, and hypothenar muscles in the hand. The lumbricals are primarily responsible for the extension at the interphalangeal joints. Therefore, in ulnar nerve palsy, there is clawing of the medial two fingers.

In ulnar nerve palsy, only the medial two fingers develop clawing, while in a combined median and ulnar nerve palsy, all four fingers develop clawing. 

The following tests are done to test the integrity of the ulnar nerve:

  • Egawa's test - In a positive test, due to the weakness of the dorsal interossei, side-to-side movements of the middle finger is weak.
  • Book test or Froment's sign - The patient is asked to hold a book between the thumb and index finger while the examiner attempt to pull it forcefully. In case of an ulnar nerve injury, the adductor pollicis is paralyzed and the patient attempts to hold the book with the flexor pollicis longus muscle supplied by the median nerve.
  • Card test - In the case of weak palmar interossei, the examiner can pull out the card with ease. 

Other options

Option B - In radial nerve palsy, the patient presents with a wrist drop due to paralyzed wrist extensors. In high lesions, there is sensory loss on the dorsum of the hand over the anatomical stuff box. 

Option C - In median nerve injury, paralysis of opponens pollicis muscle leads to ape thumb deformity. A pointing finger deformity can also be seen due to paralyzed flexors of the fingers.

Option D - Long thoracic nerve supplies the serratus anterior muscle. Patients with injury to this nerve present with winging of the scapula.

questions.text: A young patient presents to the outpatient department with complaints of icterus. The patient also gives a history of feeling stressed out due to work. On further investigation, she is found to have reduced levels of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase. Which of the following disorders is she most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is Gilbert's syndrome.

Gilbert's syndrome is a hereditary defect in bilirubin conjugation characterized by mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

A promoter region of the gene coding for the UDP-glucuronosyl transferase (UGT1A1) enzyme in Gilbert syndrome results in a variable rate of transcription of the normal enzyme. UGT1A1 activity is reduced to 10-33% of normal. It presents with mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia with other liver function tests being normal. The disorder is precipitated by stress, alcohol, and reduced caloric intake.

Liver histology shows increased lipofuscin pigment.

Gilbert's syndrome doesn't require treatment. The bilirubin levels may fluctuate over time, and patients may occasionally have jaundice, which usually resolves on its own with no ill effects.

Other options:

Option A: Type I Crigler-Najjar syndrome is characterized by a complete deficiency of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase. It usually presents as severe congenital jaundice and persists throughout life.

Options C and D: Dubin Johnson and Rotor syndrome both have elevated conjugated bilirubin in the blood, and are due to defective secretion of conjugated bilirubin into the bile.

questions.text: The peripheral smear of a patient with suspected acute leukemia shows the following characteristic finding. What is the structure marked by the arrow known as?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Auer rods, which are characteristically seen in acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

Auer rods are clumps of azurophilic granular material that appear as elongated needles, in the cytoplasm of leukemic blasts.

They can be seen in the leukemic blasts of AML and acute promyelocytic leukemia.

questions.text: A young female patient presents with severe abdominal pain. It began in the periumbilical area 10 hours ago and later migrated to the right lower quadrant of the abdomen. Acute appendicitis is an acute condition due to the inflammation of the vermiform appendix.

The symptom of migrating abdominal pain from the periumbilical area to the right iliac fossa is classic for appendicitis.

In addition, this patient has a positive Rovsing's sign, which is pain in the right iliac fossa when the left iliac fossa is deeply palpated. The abdominal pain also causes nausea and vomiting as is seen in this patient.

Other nonspecific signs of appendicitis include low-grade fever, abdominal tenderness, guarding, and rebound tenderness. McBurney's point depicting the area of maximal tenderness will also support a diagnosis of appendicitis.

questions.text: A pregnant patient in the later second trimester presents to the outpatient department with complaints of painless vaginal bleeding. She is diagnosed with the condition depicted in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image represents placenta previa.

Placenta previa is a condition characterised by partial or complete implantation of the placenta over the lower uterine segment. Patients commonly present with complaints of painless vaginal bleeding near the end of the second trimester or the third trimester.

The grades of placenta previa are:

  • Type—I (Low-lying): A significant portion of the placenta is attached to the upper segment and there is no encroachment of the os
  • Type—II (Marginal): The placenta reaches the margin of the internal os but does not cover it.
  • Type—III (Incomplete or partial central): The placenta covers the internal os partially.
  • Type—IV (Central or total): The placenta completely covers the internal os even after it is fully dilated.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient presents with a history of epilepsy. The patient's CT revealed the following findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is neurocysticercosis.

Neurocysticercosis is caused by the tapeworm Taenia solium. This disease is commonly seen in patients who consume undercooked pork and are from poor socioeconomic conditions. Patients present with adult-onset epilepsy and other features such as:

  • Psychiatric and behavioral disturbances
  • Visual disturbances
  • Features of increased intracranial tension, hydrocephalus

On imaging, four distinct stages of this disease can be made out:

  • Vesicular stage - This stage consists of viable larvae with scolex
  • Colloidal vesicular stage - The larva breaks down eliciting an immune response from the host
  • Granular nodular stage - After the larva dies and the cyst collapses, thick enhancing cyst walls with surrounding edema is seen
  • Calcified nodular stage - Edema resolves and small calcified lesions are seen

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with progressive swelling of his right wrist associated with a dull aching pain. The orthopedician elicits tenderness on firm palpation of the swelling. The following findings are seen on X-ray. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is osteoclastoma/giant cell tumor.

Osteoclastoma is a bone tumour with varying growth potential. It can be either benign/malignant, though it is more commonly benign. It is seen in patients who are 20-40 years of age. The commonly affected sites are the lower end of the femur, the upper end of the tibia, and the distal end of the radius.

Patients present with swelling and vague pain. Pathological fractures may also be seen. On examination, firm palpation can elicit tenderness. 

Radiologically, soap bubble appearance is seen due to interspersed lytic lesions and bone remnants. Intralesional curettage of the tumour is the common approach to management.

Other options

Option A: Chondrosarcoma is a malignant bone tumour arising from the cartilage cells. It may arise in any bone but is common in flat bones such as the scapula, pelvis, and ribs.

Option B: Osteosarcoma is a highly malignant primary bone tumor. Common sites are the lower end of the femur, the upper end of the tibia, and the upper end of the humerus. Patients present with a history of pain followed by swelling. Radiologically, periosteal reaction, sunburst appearance, and Codman's triangle can be seen. The characteristic sunburst appearance can be seen below.

Option D: Osteochondroma is a common benign tumour of the bone. The tumour stops enlarging in size once there is a cessation of growth at the epiphyseal plate. It is usually seen in adolescents who present with painless swelling around a joint, usually the knee. X-ray shows a well-defined exostosis as shown below.

questions.text: An elderly male patient presented with dyspepsia and epigastric pain which is relieved by eating food. Endoscopy revealed an ulcer in the anterior wall of the first part of the duodenum. Which of the following is the most common complication of the above condition?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis in this patient is an anterior duodenal ulcer and the commonest complication of this condition is perforation.

Duodenal ulcers are a form of peptic ulcer disease that commonly occurs in the first part of the duodenum.

Patients with this disease present with symptoms such as dyspepsia, and epigastric pain that is relieved by consuming food.

Anterior duodenal ulcers tend to perforate whereas posterior duodenal ulcers tend to bleed due to erosion of the gastroduodenal artery.

questions.text: An elderly female patient presented to the surgeon with a history of breast pain and a lump in her right breast for the past 2 months. On examination, the breast appears red, swollen and has an orange peel-like appearance, as shown in the image below. This finding occurs due to:

choices.text: Infiltration of tumour cells in intralobular stroma

questions.solution:
The image depicts a patient with peau d'orange or skin of an orange appearance, caused due to obstruction of subcutaneous lymphatics.

The blockage of subcuticular lymphatics leads to oedema, which deepens the mouth of the sweat glands and hair follicles. This gives rise to a typical orange peel appearance called peau d'orange, as shown in the image below. It is a classical sign of breast carcinoma.

Breast cancer is a commonly seen neoplasm in women of advancing age. Patients present with a breast lump and significant axillary lymphadenopathy, and in rare cases, breast pain may be seen. 

Inflammatory breast carcinoma (stage T4d) is an aggressive form of locally advanced breast cancer (LABC) and is associated with the worst prognosis among all subtypes of breast cancer. It accounts for <3% of breast cancers. It is characterized by skin changes of brawny induration, erythema, and edema (peau d’orange). The term peau d’orange describes the orange-peel appearance of the skin resulting from oedema and dimpling at sites of hair follicles.

Other options :

Option A: Infiltration of Cooper’s ligaments leads to dimpling of the skin.

Option C: Infiltration of the lactiferous ducts leads to nipple retraction.

Option D: Infiltration of tumour cells in intralobular stroma leads to phyllodes tumour. It is a fibroepithelial tumour arising from the intralobular stroma. It presents as a smooth, rapidly growing, multinodular, painless breast lump that is usually palpable.

Note: While Peau d’orange indicates skin involvement, dimpling of the skin and nipple retraction do not indicate skin involvement.

questions.text: The lining epithelium of the esophagus of a middle-aged male patient is made up of two types of cells as depicted in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image demonstrates squamous epithelium and columnar epithelium. This is a type of metaplasia that is seen in patients with Barrett's esophagus.

Normally the esophagus is lined by squamous epithelium, in patients with Barrett's esophagus this epithelium is replaced by specialized columnar epithelium.

Barrett's is a premalignant condition and patients with this disease usually have a chronic history of gastroesophageal reflux disease. Patients present with symptoms such as heartburn and dysphagia.

questions.text: An elderly male patient presents to the outpatient department with a palpable umbilical lymph node as shown in the image below. This finding is usually associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution: The image is that of a patient with a palpable umbilical lymph node also known as Sister Mary Joseph's nodule. This finding is pathognomic of advanced gastric carcinoma.

questions.text: A young female patient with a history of several episodes of bipolar disorder is brought to the emergency ward after she was found in a state of distress with several empty bottles of her medication. On examination, she appears confused, and agitated and has coarse tremors, ataxia, and hyperreflexia. Which of the following drugs is likely to have caused her symptoms?
questions.solution:
The patient's history of bipolar disorder along with central nervous symptoms such as confusion, agitation, coarse tremors, ataxia, and hyperreflexia point toward a possible diagnosis of lithium toxicity.

Lithium is a mood stabilizer that is used in the treatment of acute mania and bipolar disorder.

Lithium has a narrow therapeutic index and hence frequent monitoring of serum lithium concentration is necessary for patients who are on lithium therapy.

0.5-0.8 mEq/L is considered ideal for maintenance therapy in patients with bipolar disorder whereas a serum lithium concentration of 0.8-1.2 mEq/L is required in patients with episodes of acute mania.

Initially, lithium toxicity presents with symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, mild diarrhea, and fine tremors. Nervous system toxicity manifests as coarse tremors, ataxia, giddiness, ataxia, motor incoordination, nystagmus, confusion, slurred speech, and hyperreflexia.

Related Pearl: Lithium in bipolar disorder

Mania, hypomania, bipolar disorder, etc.

questions.text: During your ICU rotations, you see a  patient being ventilated with the following apparatus. What does the part marked as A represent?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a self-inflating bag and mask and the part marked as A represents the oxygen inlet.

Bag and mask ventilation is used as a first step in airway management. It serves as a rescue technique to provide oxygenation and ventilation in patients with difficult airways until tracheal intubation is achieved. 

Mask ventilation is not preferred in patients with an increased risk of regurgitation. It should be used with caution in patients with severe facial trauma.
