questions.text: An eight-month-old child is brought to the outpatient department for evaluation. The child appears as shown in the below image. The mid-upper arm circumference is 11 cm and there is no evidence of edema. The child is alert and irritable. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The alert and irritable child with severe fat wasting in the areas of the shoulders, arms, buttocks, and thighs is likely to have marasmus. 

Marasmus is a type of malnutrition which occurs due to insufficient overall calorie intake. It is characterized by severe wasting.

The child appears to be very thin, having a skin and bones appearance with no fat. The loss of buccal fat leads to the monkey facies or old man face due to its aged and wrinkled appearance. Baggy pants appearance is due to the presence of loose skin in the buttocks that hangs low. 

Diagnosis of severe acute malnutrition is made with the help of anthropometry.

  • Weight for height is below -3 standard deviations for the mean on the World Health Organization (WHO) chart  or,
  • Presence of bipedal edema or,
  • Middle-upper arm circumference (MUAC) is less than 11.5 cm

Other options: 

Option A - Kwashiorkor is a type of protein-energy malnutrition. It is characterized mainly by pitting edema starting in the legs and feet and spreading to the hands and face. They also show skin changes characterized by increased pigmentation and desquamation. 

 Option C - Chronic pancreatitis can mimic malnutrition. It can occur due to cystic fibrosis and obstruction of the pancreatic ducts. This would present with prolonged abdominal pain, weight loss, and steatorrhea. 

Option D - Marasmic kwashiorkor is a mixed form of malnutrition that presents features of both marasmus and kwashiorkor. Children present with edema, with less severe hair and skin changes of kwashiorkor. They will have some features of marasmus.

questions.text: During your surgical rotations, you see a patient with the following postoperative wound in the ward. What is the likely surgical procedure that this patient has undergone?
questions.solution:
The patient in the above image has likely undergone fasciotomy. Fasciotomy is an emergency procedure used to treat acute compartment syndrome by decompressing the affected compartment.

Acute compartment syndrome is characterized by increased pressure in the fascial compartment impairing circulation.

Patients present with symptoms such as ischemia, pain out of proportion, and paresthesia of the affected compartment/limb.

Other options:

Option C: Saucerisation is a surgical procedure used in the management of chronic osteomyelitis.

Option D: Debridement is a surgical procedure used to remove devitalised tissue and other debris from wounds. This in turn, favors wound healing

questions.text: An elderly man with a history of chain smoking is being evaluated for exertional dyspnea, and cough. His chest CT is given below. What is it suggestive of?
questions.solution:
The CT scan shows emphysematous lungs, with reduced parenchymal markings and focal areas of low attenuation.

This represents the emphysematous destruction of the lung, indicative of hyperinflation.

Radiographic studies in COPD show:

  • Emphysematous bullae
  • A paucity of parenchymal markings
  • Hyperlucency suggests the presence of emphysema
  • Increased lung volumes and flattening of the diaphragm suggest hyperinflation

questions.text: A patient in the emergency department has the following findings on ECG. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Lateral wall myocardial infarction is the likely diagnosis in this patient.

The patient's ECG demonstrates elevated ST segments in lead I and aVL. In such an infarction, the left anterior descending or the left circumflex coronary is involved.

Additionally, a posterior wall myocardial infarction is also likely in this patient due to ST segment depression in lead III. Posterior wall infarctions are difficult to diagnose and usually are associated with other myocardial infarctions such as lateral wall infarction.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child is brought to the pediatric outpatient department with complaints of high-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, and brassy cough for the past 5 days. His chest X-ray is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is croup. Infectious croup (laryngitis/laryngotracheobronchitis) is a viral infection caused mainly by the parainfluenza virus type I.

It mainly affects children between 6 months to 3 years of age. Children present with symptoms such as brassy cough, inspiratory stridor, hoarseness, or respiratory distress.

Radiographically, tapering of the upper trachea can be visualized on a chest x-ray. This is also called the steeple sign sign.

Patients with mild laryngitis/laryngotracheobronchitis are managed symptomatically with antipyretics, dexamethasone, and inhaled budesonide. Severe croup warrants urgent inpatient admission with oxygen inhalation.

Related Pearl: Acute stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

questions.text: A mother brings her child to the pediatric outpatient department complaining of poor feeding. Her child, a 15-month-old boy has a length-for-age less than–2 standard deviations below the median. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A length-for-age less than –2 standard deviations (SD) below the median is called stunting according to WHO. If the length-for-age is between −2 to −3 SD, it is called moderate stunting. Length for age below -3 SD is called severe stunting.

Other options:

Option A: A diagnosis of acute malnutrition is made with the help of weight for height charts.

Option B: A diagnosis of severe wasting can be made with mid-upper arm circumference measurements and weight for height. A mid-upper arm circumference less than 115mm or weight for height below -3SD is called severe wasting.

Option C: To diagnose a child as underweight, weight for age charts are used. If the weight for age of a child is less than 90% of the median, then the child is said to be underweight.

questions.text: A child playing unsupervised was brought with complaints of difficulty in swallowing for the last few hours.  The plain radiograph image is given below. What is the diagnosis?

choices.text: Soft tissue calcification in the neck

questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and radiograph findings are suggestive of a foreign body in the esophagus. An impacted circular radiopaque foreign object is visualized on the patient's radiograph.

Foreign body impaction in the esophagus is common in children. The most common foreign body is a food bolus and this is usually suggestive of an underlying disease.

Radioopaque foreign bodies such as button batteries and coins can be visualized on a plain radiograph. These foreign bodies can be usually removed with flexible endoscopy.

questions.text: An alcoholic patient presented with severe abdominal pain and elevated lipase levels. On examination, the following finding is noted. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is acute pancreatitis. The image is that of a patient with flank ecchymosis, this is known as the Grey Turner sign and is seen in patients with acute pancreatitis.

Acute pancreatitis is a rapidly progressing inflammatory condition of the pancreas associated with significant mortality and morbidity.

The major risk factors for developing this condition are the presence of gallstones and alcohol abuse.

Patients present with moderate to severe epigastric pain associated with vomiting and loss of appetite. On examination, there is guarding and abdominal tenderness. Rarely, patients may present with Grey Turner and Cullen signs. Grey Turner sign is characterized by flank ecchymosis whereas in Cullen sign patients present with periumbilical ecchymosis.

Related Pearl: Causes of acute pancreatitis

Common causes

  • Gallstones - most common
  • Alcohol
  • Post-ERCP (Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography)
  • Blunt trauma, abdomen
  • Post-operative (cardiothoracic, upper gastrointestinal, biliary)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Sphincter of Oddi dysfunction

Uncommon causes

  • Hyperparathyroidism
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Deficiency of apolipoprotein CII
  • Pancreas divisum
  • Periampullary diverticulum
  • Vasculitis
  • Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP)
  • Connective tissue disorders
  • Ischemic–hypoperfusion states
  • Hereditary pancreatitis
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Renal failure

Drugs

  • L-Asparaginase
  • Steroids
  • Sulfonamides
  • Tetracycline
  • Valproate
  • Azathioprine
  • Anti-retroviral drugs
  • Estrogens
  • Thiazide diuretics

Rare causes

  • Autoimmune
  • Infections (mumps, coxsackie B, cytomegalovirus, parasite)
  • Malnutrition
  • Scorpion bite

Related Pearl: Clinical features of acute pancreatitis

Symptoms:

  • Acute onset of epigastric pain, which is severe, constant, and refractory to usual doses of analgesics.
  • Typically radiates to back
  • Relieved in the sitting forward position
  • Nausea, repeated vomiting, retching, and hiccups

Signs:

  • Hypotension, tachycardia, and tachypnea
  • Grey Turner sign (A): bluish discoloration of the flanks
  • Cullen’s sign (B): bluish discoloration around the umbilicus
  • Fox sign: discoloration below the inguinal ligament
  • Pleural effusion (left > right): dullness on percussion, decreased breath sounds

Related Pearl: Laboratory findings in acute pancreatitis

  • Elevated serum amylase and serum lipase
    • Serum amylase level rises immediately and peaks in few hours and returns to normal in 3–5 days
    • Serum amylase level lacks specificity.
    • Serum amylase levels do not correlate with the severity of pancreatitis.
    • Serum lipase is more specific, and it is more useful when the patient presents 24–48 hours later.
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hypocalcemia, hypoalbuminemia
  • Leukocytosis
  • Elevated serum levels of hepatic enzymes like alanine aminotransferase (ALT).
  • Azotemia, due to prerenal acute renal failure in case of severe fluid loss

questions.text: A 33-year-old man was referred to the surgery OPD with complaints of infertility. On inspection, the scrotum appeared as in the image. On palpation, a bag of worms sensation was felt. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is a varicocele.

Varicocele is a disease characterized by abnormal dilatation of the veins draining the testis. It is seen in patients with incompetence or absence of valves in the proximal testicular vein.

Patients present with symptoms such as discomfort worsened by standing. On palpation, the varicosities feel like a bag of worms. Mild testicular atrophy may also be seen in patients with long-standing varicocele. Varicoceles are commonly seen in patients with infertility, though the exact mechanism is unclear.

Usually, these patients require no surgical management if there is no significant discomfort. In the case of patients with significant discomfort, percutaneous embolization or surgical ligation of the gonadal veins may be attempted.

questions.text: A concerned mother presents to the outpatient department with complaints of reddish vaginal discharge after 3 days of delivery. Her vitals were stable and there were no associated signs of sepsis. What is this known as?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lochia rubra.

Lochia is a type of vaginal discharge seen in the first fortnight during puerperium. Depending on the color it is named as:

  • Lochia rubra is red in color and seen during the first 1-4 days.
  • Lochia serosa is yellowish or pale brownish and seen during the initial 5-9 days.
  • Lochia alba is pale white in appearance and is seen 10-15 days postpartum.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presented with complaints of easy irritability and insomnia for the past 2 years. The patient's wife states that these episodes usually alternate with periods where her husband complains of feeling hopeless, low mood, and dejected. The patient denies using drugs, or consuming alcohol and states that he has been this way for as long as he remembers. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in a patient experiencing alternate periods of irritability and feeling dejected for a period greater than 2 years is cyclothymic disorder.

Cyclothymia is a mild form of bipolar II disorder, characterized by symptoms of hypomania and mild depression. Hypomania mainly includes symptoms like persistently elevated or irritable mood and abnormally increased energy for a minimum duration of at least 4 days.

The depression seen in cyclothymia does not qualify the criteria for a major depressive episode.

Alcohol abuse and other substance abuse are commonly seen in patients with cyclothymic disorder. These patients use these drugs to self-medicate or to achieve even further stimulation.

Mood stabilizers like lithium and antimanic drugs like sodium valproate are the first lines of treatment. Psychotherapy is a great way for patients to develop coping mechanisms to help with their mood swings. Patients often require life-long treatment.

Option A: Major depressive disorder usually presents with depressed mood, anhedonia, significant change in weight or appetite, insomnia or hypersomnia, fatigue, and feelings of worthlessness nearly every day. These symptoms are present for a minimum of 2 weeks. 

Option C: Adjustment disorder is characterized by emotional or behavioral symptoms that develop within 3 months of exposure to an identifiable stressor and usually do not last more than 6 months after the stressor ends.

Option D: Dysthymic disorder is the presence of a persistently depressed mood that lasts most of the day and is continuous. There are also feelings of guilt, irritability, and anger associated with it. These symptoms are present for at least 2 years. Episodes of mania/hypomania are not seen in this condition.

Related Pearl: Patterns of Mood Disorders

questions.text: A patient undergoes the procedure shown in the image below. Which of the following micronutrient deficiencies should the physician anticipate in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image depicts a Roux-en y gastric bypass (RYGB). Patients who undergo this procedure commonly develop iron deficiency.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of sudden onset headache, palpitation, and profuse sweating. The patient has had multiple similar episodes in the past. During these episodes, the patient's blood pressure is elevated. A 24-hour urinary metanephrine is elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is pheochromocytoma.

Pheochromocytoma is a rare tumor of the sympathetic system arising from the adrenal medulla.

Patients commonly present with a classical triad of palpitation, headache, and profuse sweating. Patients also present with hypertension and cardiac arrhythmias. These symptoms are due to an excess of catecholamines secreted by the tumor.

Related Pearl: Pheochromocytoma

Features:

  • When pheochromocytoma is associated with the MEN syndrome it is rarely malignant.
  • Phaeochromocytomas are greyish-pink on the cut surface and are usually highly vascularised.
  • Zellbalen cells and nuclei with salt and pepper chromatin are seen.

Factors indicating more chances of malignancy:

  • An increased PASS (phaeochromocytoma of the adrenal gland scale score)
  • High number of Ki-67-positive cells
  • Vascular invasion or a breached capsule

Diagnosis:

  • Urinary catecholamine and VMA level assay are most sensitive screening test.
  • MRI is the IOC.
  • Biopsy and CT Contrast scan are contraindicated in order to avoid Hypertensive crisis.

Treatment:

  • Adrenalectomy is preferred TOC.
  • Size<5 cm -  Laparoscopic adrenalectomy
  • Preop Alpha blockers should be given
  • Mitotane should be started as adjuvant or palliative treatment

    • Profuse sweating

  • Weight loss
  • Polyuria and polydipsia

questions.text: A patient at the emergency department is diagnosed with bleeding from esophageal varices. What type of shock is this patient at risk for?
questions.solution:
The patient in the above scenario is at risk of developing hypovolemia shock.

Shock is defined as a systemic state of low tissue perfusion which is inadequate for normal cellular respiration.

Shock can be classified as follows:

Shock Inciting mechanism
Hypovolemic shock

Reduced circulating blood volume

(eg., hemorrhage, dehydration)
Cardiogenic shock

Failure of the cardiac pump

(eg., myocardial infarction, cardiac dysrhythmias)
Obstructive shock

Mechanical obstruction of cardiac filling 

(eg., cardiac tamponade, tension pneumothorax)
Distributive shock

Systemic vasodilation leading to organ hypoperfusion

(eg., anaphylaxis due to histamine release, sepsis due to the release of bacterial products, spinal cord injury due to sympathetic failure)
Endocrine shock

Combination of hypovolemic, cardiogenic or distributive shock.

(eg., hypo and hyperthyroidism, adrenal insufficiency)

questions.text: An infant is brought to the emergency department with a history of excessive crying. On examination, there is abdominal distension and tenderness. A barium enema is done and the image is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in the above infant is intussusception. 

Intussusception is a condition characterized by the invagination of one segment of the bowel into another. It may be ileocolic, colocolic or ileoileal. It is speculated that upper respiratory tract infections causing edema of the Peyer patches is an etiological factor in children.

Infants are commonly brought to the emergency department with complaints of bouts of excessive crying, abdominal mass, and passage of red currant jelly stool.

Ultrasound is the investigation of choice and it shows the target/ doughnut sign. On barium enema, these children demonstrate a characteristic claw sign(shown below).  

Other options:

Option B: Patients with sigmoid volvulus demonstrate the omega sign or the coffee bean sign.

Option C: Duodenal atresia is commonly seen in newborns. Babies usually present with bilious/non-bilious vomiting immediately after birth. A plain X-ray abdomen reveals two foci of gas, one in the stomach and the other in the duodenum called the double bubble sign.

Option D: Intestinal obstruction presents with abdominal pain, distension and constipation. A plain radiograph of the abdomen shows multiple air-fluid levels.

questions.text: A female patient at 33 weeks of gestation was diagnosed with severe preeclampsia. The patient was given a loading dose of 14g MgSO4, followed by 5g intramuscularly every 4 hours in the alternate buttocks. Which regimen is being followed here?
questions.solution:
The regimen being followed here is Pritchard regimen.

Preeclampsia is a multisystem disorder of pregnancy characterized by hypertension and proteinuria.

Patients present with elevated blood pressure, proteinuria, thrombocytopenia, cerebral and visual symptoms, intrauterine growth restriction of the fetus, and pulmonary edema. Patients with severe preeclampsia eventually eclamptic convulsions.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with symptoms of a stroke. What is the window period up to which intravenous thrombolysis can be done?
questions.solution:
The window period for thrombolysis in case of stroke is 4.5 hours.

Recombinant tissue plasminogen activator(rTPA)is used for intravenous thrombolysis. This drug is effective for up to 4.5 hours of stroke onset.

questions.text: A young female patient presents with painful menses, pain during intercourse, and infertility. Per vaginal examination reveals tenderness in the lateral fornices with a normal-sized nulligravid uterus. A speculum exam reveals bluish-puckered spots in the posterior fornix. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is endometriosis. 

Endometriosis is a condition that is characterized by the presence of endometrial tissue outside the cavity of the uterus. The three categories of endometriosis are:

  • Pelvic endometriosis
  • Ovarian endometriosis/Chocolate cyst
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis

Patients present with symptoms such as dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, lower abdominal pain, infertility, and menorrhagia.

Per speculum examination of these patients reveals bluish or blackish puckered spots in the posterior fornix that are tender to touch. The presence of these spots is pathognomic of endometriosis. Vaginal examination reveals tenderness in the lateral fornices.

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: The non-communicable disease (NCD)  clinic at the district hospital screens people above the age of 50 years with positive family history for diabetes.  What type of screening is this?
questions.solution:
The non-communicable disease/ NCD clinic at the district hospital screening people above the age of 50 years for diabetes is a type of high-risk screening. 

Screening is searching or testing for diseases or defects that are not evident in apparently healthy individuals. 

High-risk or selective screening is screening applied selectively to high-risk groups defined on the basis of epidemiological research. For example, screening the other members in families of patients with diabetes or hypertension. It is an effective and economical method of screening.  

Other options:

Option A: Mass screening is the screening of a population or a sub-group of the population for a disease irrespective of the particular risk an individual may run of contracting the disease in question.

Option B: Multiphasic screening is the application of two or more screening tests (instead of carrying out separate screening tests for a single disease) to a large number of people in the form of health questionnaires, clinical examinations, and investigations. 

Option C: Prospective screening is screening people for the benefit of others. For example, screening immigrants for infectious diseases such as tuberculosis to protect the home population from the disease.

questions.text: An 18-month-old child was brought to the clinic with a history of fever, cough, and cold. On examination, respiratory rate was 46/min. Which is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Administer IV antibiotics and refer to higher centre
Administer oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs, and send home

questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this child is pneumonia. The most appropriate management would be to start oral antibiotics, parents warned of danger signs and sent home.

Children with symptoms of fever, cough, cold, fast breathing, chest indrawing, and no danger signs are termed to have pneumonia. These children can be managed conservatively with oral antibiotics such as amoxicillin for 5 days. Fast breathing is defined as the respiratory rate of:

  • ≥ 50/min in 2 months to 1 year
  • ≥ 40/min in >1–5 years
  • ≥ 30/min >5 years

The danger signs are listed below:

  • Not able to drink
  • Persistent vomiting
  • Convulsions, lethargic or unconscious
  • Stridor in a calm child
  • Severe malnutrition

questions.text: A patient presents with hip pain and apparent lengthening of the limb which was diagnosed as tuberculosis of the hip. Which stage of the disease is he currently in?
questions.solution:
In a patient with tuberculosis of the hip, apparent lengthening of the limb is seen in stage I which is known as the stage of synovitis.

Clinical features seen in the stages of TB hip are:

  • The stage of synovitis presents with apparent lengthening of the limb.
  • The stage of arthritis presents with apparent shortening of the limb.
  • The stage of erosion presents with true shortening of the limb.

Note: The apparent length of the limb is measured from the xiphisternum to the medial malleolus. The true length of the limb is measured from the anterior superior iliac spine to the medial malleolus.

questions.text: A 7-month-old child presents with Hb 6.3g/dL with a history of repeated blood transfusions. Peripheral smear shows a hypochromic microcytic picture with normal leukocytes and platelets. Which of the following tests can be used to screen for and also diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of repeated transfusions, low hemoglobin, and a hypochromic microcytic picture in the smear suggests thalassemia. Hemoglobin electrophoresis can be used to screen for and also diagnose this condition.

Alpha- and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively. This leads to the precipitation of the excess (unpaired) chains, interfering with red blood cell (RBC) production and survival. Disease severity is inversely correlated with the number of functioning globin chains.

Clinical features seen in thalassemia are:

  • Anemia
  • Jaundice and pigment gallstones
  • Thalassemic facies including features such as maxilla hyperplasia, flat nasal bridge, and frontal bossing
  • Growth impairment
  • Splenomegaly
  • Endocrine abnormalities including hypogonadism, hypothyroidism, diabetes mellitus
  • Heart failure and arrhythmias

Repeated blood transfusions are the mainstay of management.

Related Pearl: Thalassemia syndromes

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Alpha thalassemia: Gene deletion is the most common cause of reduced α-chain synthesis.
  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.

questions.text: An infant is brought to the pediatric outpatient department for routine evaluation. The physician uses a cube to evaluate the child's grasp. The child grasps the cube with ulnar aspect of his hand. What is the approximate age of the child?

The approximate age of the child is 6 months since he is grasping the cube with the ulnar aspect of hand.

questions.text: During a surgical procedure under general anesthesia, the patient suddenly develops hyperthermia, muscle rigidity, and tachycardia. Which of the following anesthetic agents is likely responsible for the patient developing this condition?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in a patient who developed hyperthermia, muscle rigidity, and tachycardia while undergoing surgery under general anesthesia is malignant hyperthermia. Inhaled general anesthetics such as desflurane are known to trigger this condition.

Related Pearl: Malignant hyperthermia key features

Pathophysiology:

  • Prolonged opening of functionally altered ryanodine receptors, leading to uncontrolled release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum resulting in sustained muscle contraction.

Drugs known to trigger malignant hyperthermia:

  • Inhaled anesthetics: Halothane, Isoflurane, Sevoflurane, Desflurane, Ether, Methoxyflurane
  • Depolarising muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine

Clinical signs:

  • Increased metabolism: Increased EtCO2, decreased SpO2, metabolic acidosis
  • Increased sympathetic activity: Tachycardia, hypertension, arrythmia
  • Muscle damage: Masseter spasm, generalised rigidity, hyperkalemia, rhabdomyolysis, myoglobinuria
  • Hyperthermia: Fever, sweating

 Treatment: 

  • Discontinuation of all anesthetic agents
  • Hyperventilation with 100% O2
  • Dantrolene: 2.5 mg/kg intravenously every 5 min until the episode is terminated (upper limit - 10 mg/kg).
  • Correction of acid-base, electrolyte abnormality 
  • Cooling the patient

questions.text: A young boy with Down's Syndrome presents with large warty crusts on his hands and feet. Scaling of the skin over the face, neck and trunk is also seen. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is Norwegian/crusted scabies. 

This disease occurs in patients with an inadequate immune response to the mite, allowing it to multiply in huge numbers.

It is commonly seen in patients who suffer from conditions such as dementia, and Down's syndrome. It is speculated that patients with these conditions develop crusted scabies due to their lack of appreciation of pruritus.

Patients commonly present with large warty crusts on their hands and feet. Palms and soles may be irregularly thickened and fissured. There may be scaling of the face, neck, scalp, and trunk.

questions.text:
The arterial blood gas of a patient in the emergency department is as follows. What is the likely diagnosis?

pH = 7.12

pCO2 = 50 mm Hg

HCO3 = 28 mEq/L
questions.solution:
Based on the above arterial blood gas values, the likely diagnosis in this patient is respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation.

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: pH is reduced (7.12), hence acidosis.

Step 2: Since there is a significant increase in pCO2(50 mmHg), it is respiratory acidosis.

Step 3: There is a mild elevation in HCO3 (28 mEq/L) suggesting that there is metabolic compensation.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: A young female patient presents to the outpatient department with oligomenorrhea, acne, and increased facial hair. Which of the following is not an expected finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Streak ovaries/gonads are a characteristic finding in patients with Turner's syndrome. It is not seen in polycystic ovarian syndrome(PCOS).

Polycystic ovarian syndrome(PCOS) is an endocrinopathy characterized by anovulation, insulin resistance, clinical signs of androgen excess, and multiple ovarian cysts. Patients with this disorder present with oligomenorrhea or amenorrhea, increased facial hair, and acne. Other features that can be seen in this condition are dyslipidemia, obstructive sleep apnea, acanthosis nigricans, hair loss, and an increased risk of endometrial cancer. 

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone >2 ng/mL, free T >2.2 pg/mL (Normal level 0.2–0.8 ng/mL)
    • Normal androstenedione level is 1.3–1.5 ng/mL
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

questions.text: A young child requires inhaled corticosteroids. You attach the device shown below to the pressurized metered-dose inhaler for ease of use. Which of the following statement is not true about this device?

choices.text: Decreases the deposition of drug on the oropharynx
Increases the amount of drug entering the lower airways
Increases the incidence of oropharyngeal candidiasis
Can be used in small children

questions.solution:
The given image is that of a spacer.

It decreases the incidence of oropharyngeal candidiasis and other local adverse effects associated with inhaled corticosteroid use.

Spacers reduce the velocity and size of particles entering the upper airways. This reduces the amount of drug that impinges on the oropharynx and increases the proportion of drug inhaled into lower airways. 

Spacer devices are useful in delivering inhaled drugs to children who are not able to use a metered dose inhaler.

questions.text:
Recently, a new latex agglutination test was approved for the screening of a disease. Calculate the sensitivity and specificity based on the table given below:
  Test +ve Test -ve
Disease+ 27 3
Disease - 5 95
questions.solution:
• Let us first reconstruct the table to indicate true (TP/TN) and false (FP/FN) positives and negatives.
  Test + Test -
Diseased 27 (TP) 3 (FN)
Not diseased 5 (FP) 95 (TN)
  • Sensitivity is given as TP/(TP + FN) x 100 and specificity is given as TN/(FP + TN) x 100
  • In this scenario, sensitivity is 90% and specificity is 95%

Related Pearl: Evaluation of diagnostic tests

Different ways of asking the following parameters:

Sensitivity (True positive rate) 

  • Percentage of diseased individuals who are correctly identified (as diseased).
  • Proportion of all people with the disease who test positive.
  • Probability that when the disease is present, the test is positive.

Specificity (True negative rate) 

  • Percentage of healthy individuals who are correctly identified (as healthy).
  • Proportion of all people without the disease who test negative.
  • Probability that when the disease is absent, the test is negative.

Positive predictive value 

  • Probability that a person who has a positive test result actually has the disease.
  • If the test is positive, what is the probability that the patient has the disease?

Negative predictive value 

  • Probability that a person who has a negative test result actually does not have the disease.
  • If the test is negative, what is the probability that the patient does not have the disease?

questions.text: A man was brought to the ER after being involved in a fistfight with a bartender, presenting with severe chest pain, dyspnea, distended neck veins, and hypotension (80/50 mmHg). He subsequently collapsed. On examination, percussion revealed hyper resonance in the infraclavicular region with absent breath sounds on the left. A chest X-ray showed a tracheal shift to the right. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray features showing a well-demarcated area devoid of lung markings on the left side with tracheal deviation and the mediastinal shift to the right side, along with the clinical scenario is suggestive of tension pneumothorax. 

Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis, and treatment should never be delayed while waiting for radiological confirmation. Imaging modalities used are ultrasound–extended focused assessment with sonar for trauma (eFAST), chest x-ray, and spiral CT.

A tension pneumothorax develops when there is a tear either in the parietal or visceral pleura. This tear acts as a one-way valve i.e., air enters from the lung or chest wall through it during inspiration but has no way to escape during expiration. This ultimately leads to the collapse of the affected lung.

It usually occurs following penetrating or blunt chest trauma, iatrogenic lung injury, or mechanical positive pressure ventilation.

It is characterized by:

  • Chest pain
  • Tachypnea and acute dyspnea
  • Sudden onset hemodynamic compromise (tachycardia, hypotension, low O2 saturation, loss of consciousness)
  • Neck vein distention
  • Tracheal deviation away from the side of the injury
  • Decreased chest movements on the affected side
  • Hyper-resonance on percussion on the affected side
  • Absence or decreased breath sounds on the affected side

The X-ray below shows a left-sided tension pneumothorax. There is a large, well-demarcated area devoid of lung markings on the left side. The yellow arrows are pointing towards the tracheal deviation and the mediastinal shift to the right side.

Management of tension pneumothorax:

  • Immediate management- needle decompression or needle thoracostomy i.e. insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line
  • Definitive management- tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety, identified as a triangle that lies anterior to the midaxillary line above the nipple, below, and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.

Other Options:

Option B: Pleural effusion may present with dyspnea, pleuritic pain, dry cough, and associated symptoms like fever, weight loss, oedema, and ascites depending on the aetiology. On examination, there may be tachypnea, dullness on percussion and decreased/absent breath sounds at the base(s).

Option C: Constrictive pericarditis symptoms may include swelling in the legs, fatigue, and discomfort, but it's not directly associated with reduced breath sounds or hyperresonance.

Option D: Pneumomediastinum presents with clinical features include severe substernal chest pain (may or may not radiate to the neck and arms) and subcutaneous emphysema over the suprasternal notch.

questions.text: A patient presents to the medicine outpatient department with a report showing significantly elevated thyroid stimulating hormone and low levels of free T4. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?

questions.text: A young female patient presents with fever, chills, and abdominal pain 2 days after an uneventful vaginal delivery. The patient is diagnosed with postpartum endometritis. Which among the following is false about her condition?

choices.text: Risk of developing this condition is more with vaginal delivery when compared with caesarian section
Prolonged labour is a risk factor for developing this condition
Patients are treated with oral or parenteral antimicrobials

questions.solution:
The single most important risk factor for developing postpartum endometritis is cesarean birth. Hence the statement that the risk of this developing this condition is greater with vaginal delivery is false.

Postpartum endometritis is an infective condition of the genital tract. The majority of the infections are polymicrobial and are caused by the bacteria present in the genital tract. Important conditions increasing the risk of developing endometritis are cesarean section, prolonged labor, and chorioamnionitis. Patients present with symptoms such as fever, abdominal tenderness, and other features of sepsis.

Oral or parenteral antibiotics are the mainstay of treatment.

questions.text: A child is brought to the emergency department with swelling and pain over the proximal forearm. The mother claims that the child fell on an outstretched hand while playing with friends. The radiograph shows the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The plain radiograph shows a fracture of the proximal ulna along with a dislocation of the head of the radius. This type of injury is termed a Monteggia fracture.

Patients present with symptoms such as swelling and pain in the proximal forearm region. The mechanism of injury in such a fracture is usually a fall on an outstretched hand or a direct injury to the back of the upper forearm.

Monteggia fracture is an unstable fracture and is usually managed surgically with open reduction and internal fixation.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar displacement.

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius.

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of the ulnar bone.

questions.text: When is cord clamping ideally done?
questions.solution:
As per the AMTSL guidelines, cord clamping is practised within 1-3 minutes of the delivery of the fetus.

Delayed cord clamping is done 30 to 60 seconds after birth in all the babies. This increases the amount of blood flowing from mother to baby which decreases the risk of anaemia in later life, improves hemodynamic stability, decreases the risk of necrotizing enterocolitis,intraventricular hemorrhage in preterm infants, and also decreases the need for transfusions and inotropic support.

AMTSL guidelines recommended by WHO :

  • Immediate administration of prophylactic uterotonics (Oxytocin). Oxytocin (10 IU) is given IM or IV.
  • Controlled cord traction during placental delivery (in cesarean section and in vaginal birth where skilled birth attendants are present)
  • Delayed cord clamping
  • Postpartum abdominal uterine tonus assessment for early identification of uterine atony is recommended for all women. Continuous monitoring of uterine tone is done every 15 minutes for 2 hours. If uterine atony is detected, a fundal massage is performed.

Recent update: Uterine massage is not recommended routinely.

The goal of this is to prevent postpartum haemorrhage (PPH). Hence, uterotonics are the most important factor in decreasing PPH. Delayed cord clamping is a less important component in this direction and similarly, cord traction is not as critical. Uterine massage does not form the main component of AMTSL.

questions.text: A  patient was brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. His CT scan is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given CT image shows a crescent-shaped lesion that crosses suture lines and is indicative of acute subdural hematoma/hemorrhage.

Subdural hemorrhage (SDH) is a collection of blood between the dura and the arachnoid layers of the meninges. Most commonly, it results from the rupture of cortical bridging veins. Non-contrast CT is the investigation of choice.

Radiographic features of subdural hemorrhages:

  • Crescent-like distribution around the periphery of the brain.
  • They are not limited by sutures.
  • Crescent-shaped hypodense lesion on axial CT: Chronic subdural hemorrhage
  • Crescent-shaped hyperdense collections on CT: Acute subdural hemorrhage. 

Related Pearl: Intracranial Hemorrhage (ICH)

Extradural hemorrhage (EDH): 

  • Source: Arterial bleed
  • MC- Middle meningeal artery 
  • Cause- Trauma 
  • Clinical features: Lucid interval is characteristic 
  • CT – Lentiform opacity 
  • Treatment: A large or rapidly evolving EDH requires surgical evacuation

 

Subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous bleed 
  • Bridging dural veins 
  • Causes: Trauma, anticoagulants, antiplatelets, alcohol abuse, shaken baby syndrome 
  • Clinical features
    • Acute SDH: may be associated with lucid interval
    • Chronic SDH: drowsiness, headache
  • CT- crescentic opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH)

  • Source: Arterial bleed 
  • Causes:
    • MC – Trauma
    • 2nd MC – Rupture of berry aneurysm
  • MC sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery 
  • Clinical features: Thunderclap headache with neck stiffness +/- FND 
  • Investigations:
    • Non-contrast CT brain,
    • CSF xanthochromia (peaks in 2 days and subsides in 2 weeks) 
  • Treatment:
    • Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm,
    • Triple H therapy – hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution to prevent vasospasm 

 

Intraparenchymal hemorrhage- (MC type of ICH)

  • Source- Arterial bleed 
  • Causes:
    • MC – hypertension
    • Trauma, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, bleeding disorders, neoplasms, vascular malformations 
  • MC sites:
    • Putamen (basal ganglia)
    • Thalamus
    • Cerebellum
    • Pons 
  • Treatment:
    • Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP or fresh platelets as required
    • Surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoms >3 cm in size

questions.text: A middle-aged female patient presents with sudden bilateral swelling of lower limbs associated with diarrhea, dyspnea, and signs of cardiac failure. Mustard oil adulteration is suspected to be the cause. What is the toxin involved?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of epidemic dropsy. It is caused by the toxic compound sanguinarine, which is present in argemone oil extracted from argemone seeds. It is commonly used as an adulterant in mustard oil.

Epidemic dropsy results in sudden onset of swelling of lower limbs, diarrhea, and breathlessness. Some patients may develop glaucoma. It can lead to death due to cardiac failure.

Adulteration with argemone oil can be detected by the following tests:

  • Paper chromatography - most sensitive test
  • Nitric acid test

questions.text: A young female patient with a history of amenorrhea for 6 weeks presented with vaginal spotting, sharp abdominal pain, and abdominal tenderness.  A urine pregnancy test is positive. A transvaginal ultrasound confirms the diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy.  Where is the most common location of implantation?
questions.solution:
The most common location of implantation in ectopic pregnancy is the ampulla.

A pregnancy is considered ectopic when there is the implantation of the blastocyst at a site other than the endometrial lining of the uterus. In nearly 95% of these pregnancies, implantation occurs in the fallopian tube. The commonest site in the fallopian tube is the ampulla.

This patient with 6-week history of amenorrhea, a positive pregnancy test, and an empty uterus is likely to have an ectopic pregnancy. In addition, sharp abdominal pain, vaginal spotting, and abdominal tenderness support a diagnosis of ruptured ectopic pregnancy. 

The other sites of implantations are the ovary, cervix, or prior cesarean scar.  

Related Pearl: Fallopian tube

Gross anatomy:

The fallopian tube is divided into the following parts:

  • Intramural/Interstitial portion:  
    • Intrauterine
    • The narrowest and shortest part
  • Isthmus:
    • The most common site for tubectomy
  • Ampulla:
    • The longest part
    • The most common site for - fertilization and ectopic pregnancy
  • Infundibulum:
    • The widest part

Histology:

The ampulla, isthmus and infundibulum are extrauterine. They're covered by three layers: 

  • Mesosalpinx - It is the peritoneal layer. Also called serosa.
  • Myosalpinx - It contains smooth muscle and has 2 layers:
    • Inner circular 
    • Outer longitudinal
  • Endosalpinx - It is the mucosal layer. It has the following features:
    • Numerous branching folds, filling the entire lumen
    • Basement membrane
    • Ciliated, columnar epithelium 
    • Peg cells - non-ciliated epithelium. They help in the capacitation of sperms.

questions.text: A young male patient presents with pain during defecation along with the presence of blood-streaked stools. He has had a history of constipation for 5 months. On examination, a sentinel tag is present at the anal orifice. Due to extreme pain, a digital rectal examination is avoided. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This case scenario with a history of chronic constipation, and the presence of sentinel tags on examination, suggests a diagnosis of anal fissure.

An anal fissure is a longitudinal split in the anoderm of the distal anal canal. A chronic anal fissure frequently is associated with :

  • Sentinel tag externally
  • Hypertrophied anal papillae internally
  • Anal ulcer overlying the internal sphincter

Anal fissures are usually seen in the young but they can occur at any age with equal sex predilection. Severe pain associated with defecation resolves spontaneously and reappears during the next evacuation. It may even be associated with the passage of fresh blood. 

Most of the fissures are located in the posterior midline followed by the anterior midline. Fissures located anywhere around the anal circumference can be possible due to other diseases like HIV, tuberculosis, syphilis, Crohn's disease, or carcinoma.

Treatment of anal fissure:

  • The focus is to normalize bowel habits. Bowel softeners, dietary fibres, and adequate water should be recommended.
  • Medical therapy involves the topical application of glyceryl trinitrate. It releases nitric oxide and relaxes the internal anal sphincter. This reduces spasms, and pain and improves vasculature to promote healing.
  • Surgical therapy is recommended for chronic fissures that have failed medical therapy. Lateral internal sphincterotomy is the procedure of choice where a portion of the internal sphincter is divided away from the fissure. 

Other options:

Option A: Anal fistula is usually associated with pain and intermittent purulent discharge. On examination, an external opening in the perineum can be found which opens internally in the anal canal.

Option C: Hemorrhoids are enlargements of anal cushions which occur commonly due to raised intra-abdominal pressure(e.g. constipation and pregnancy). They present with bright-red painless bleeding, pruritus, mucus discharge, and prolapsed hemorrhoids. Pain is not a common feature and is present if haemorrhoids are thrombosed.

Option D: Rectal prolapse presents as a mass protruding out of the anal canal. It is seen more commonly in females and may be associated with faecal incontinence.

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of secondary syphilis?
questions.solution:
Moth-eaten alopecia is a feature of secondary syphilis.

Secondary syphilis is a stage of syphilis characterized by skin and mucous membrane manifestations. Rashes seen in secondary syphilis have three standard features:

  • They do not itch
  • They are coppery red in appearance
  • Rashes are symmetrical in distribution

Patients with secondary syphilis present with patchy, scattered hair loss affecting the eyebrows and beard. This pattern is termed moth-eaten alopecia.

The image below is that of a man with moth-eaten alopecia.

Related Pearl: Stages of syphilis

  • Primary Syphilis:

Chancre- Painless, indurated, usually single

Lymphadenopathy- Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes

Dory flop sign- As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.

 

Secondary Syphilis:

A & B: Generalized rash(non-itchy, no vesicles, and palm and sole involvement).

This is the most common lesion.

C & D: Condyloma lata.

E: Moth-eaten alopecia (Non-scarring)

F: Mucous patches(Flat erosions on the tongue which can coalesce and form snail track ulcers).These are the most infectious lesions.

G: Pigmentary plaques

H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions

Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

 

Tertiary Syphilis:

Gummatous syphilis(deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor)

Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  

CVS-Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta

CNS-General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

 

Latent Syphilis-Period between secondary and tertiary syphilis, when the patient is asymptomatic clinically, and only serological evidence of infection is present.

  • Early latent- Within 1 year of infection
  • Late latent- After 1 year of infection

questions.text: A middle-aged woman has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her HbA1c level at diagnosis is 11.1%. What is the initial drug of choice?
questions.solution:
Insulin is the best initial drug of choice when HbA1c is > 9% at diagnosis. 

Insulin is used in the treatment of type 2 diabetes in the following cases:

  • Inadequate glycemic control with 2 or more oral agents
  • HbA1c > 9% at diagnosis

In patients with HbA1c < 9%, metformin is the drug of choice.

Diagnosis is confirmed by demonstrating the presence of non-caseating granulomas in lung biopsies along with other manifestations of this disease.

questions.text: A patient developed a lesion as shown below a few months after undergoing heart surgery. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is a keloid scar.

Keloid is a consequence of abnormal wound healing. It is suspected that overacted fibroblasts are responsible for patients developing this condition. Keloids present as firm, rubbery nodules in areas of prior skin injury.

Keloids almost always extend beyond the initial site of an injury, in contrast to hypertrophic scar.

There is a high chance of recurrence post-surgical excision, hence this must always be paired with other modalities such as intralesional steroid injections.

Other options:

Hypertrophic scars are raised, red scars that remain within the boundaries of the original wound. They are characterized by excessive collagen formation during the healing process. Unlike keloid scars, hypertrophic scars do not extend beyond the original wound site. They may regress over time and are less likely to recur after surgical excision.

Atrophic scars are characterized by a depression in the skin's surface, often resulting from a loss of underlying tissue. They can occur due to conditions like acne or trauma. They are the opposite of hypertrophic and keloid scars, as they result in a loss of tissue rather than excessive collagen formation.

Contractures are scars that cause the skin to tighten and pull, leading to reduced mobility of nearby structures. They can occur after burns or extensive tissue damage. Contractures are characterized by tightening and pulling of the skin, leading to functional limitations.
